SASKATOON ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering the questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another.

Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use "etc."

The sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the question, don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who have lived in Western Canada before 1924, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the question, they should write them on separate sheets of paper for a separate questionnaire.

11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

Canada was a place I had never heard of before, but I knew it was somewhere far away.

I traveled by myself because I wanted to make my own decisions about my future.

Field ventures continued

The next day we set out early to explore the area around the bridge. We walked down the river for about an hour before reaching the town of New Hope. From there, we continued on to the nearby village of Willow Creek.

We arrived in Willow Creek late afternoon and checked into the local inn. The next morning, we decided to take a leisurely stroll through the town before heading back to the river.

As we walked along the riverbank, we noticed a group of people gathered near the water's edge. They appeared to be engaged in some sort of activity, but from a distance, it was difficult to tell what they were doing.

We approached the group and found that they were setting up for a picnic. They had brought along sandwiches, salads, and drinks, and were preparing to enjoy a meal together.

We joined them for lunch and spent the afternoon enjoying each other's company. It was a beautiful day, and we all felt grateful for the opportunity to spend time outdoors.

After lunch, we continued our walk along the river, taking in the sights and sounds of the area. We eventually made our way back to the inn, where we prepared for our return journey home.

As we packed up our belongings, we couldn't help but feel grateful for the experiences we had shared. It was a wonderful day, and we knew that we would never forget it.
In a dream, I saw myself as the eagle rising.

Amidst chaos in 1857, my journey across the vast expanse of

America began. The road was long, filled with trials and tribulations.

On the way, I encountered harsh landscapes, the rugged wilderness,

in its wild isolation, and the harsh reality of life's challenges.

An unwavering spirit guided me through every obstacle,

on my path to freedom and self-discovery. Each step forward,

was a testament to resilience and determination.

The eagle soars high above, symbolizing hope and

inspiration. In the midst of adversity, there is always

a way to rise above, to find strength within oneself.

This journey taught me valuable lessons about

perseverance and courage. Despite the difficulties,

I learned to embrace each moment, to find joy

in the simple things. Through it all, I remained

steadfast, determined to overcome any obstacle.

In conclusion, this experience has been

transformative. It has taught me invaluable

lessons about life, about myself. I am grateful

for this opportunity to share my story, to inspire others

to follow their dreams, no matter how daunting they may seem.

This is a funny adventure of the early days.

Once upon a time in 1887, two young girls were out for a walk with their families.

The wind was blowing, the hills were green, and the trees were tall.

As they walked, they heard two young boys talking.

The boys were discussing something important.

One boy said, "We need to find a way to get home."

The other boy replied, "I have an idea! We can climb the tree and jump down."

The first boy thought this was a good idea, so they climbed the tree.

Suddenly, a group of people appeared behind them.

They were friends who had been waiting for them.

The boys explained what they were doing, and the friends helped them get back home safely.

It was a funny adventure, but they learned an important lesson about teamwork.

This is a funny adventure of the early days. Sometime in 1887, my younger sisters went out to visit their friends, the Blader girls, walking the half mile on the well-trodden path through the poplar bluffs. On arriving they found two young bucks having tea by themselves. The girls not knowing that these boys understood some English started to ask each other which one they'd prefer for their fellow. One girl would say, "the one with the most rings & beads in his plaited hair," the other preferred the one with the tiniest as ornaments; they'd come hardly to see worth! Well, when the girls left for home, accompanied by their nieces, they suddenly heard a whoop & yelling behind them. It was their friends, the Indians, wielding lances as if to catch the girls & calling out "I'll be your fellow, come on get on my back!" The girls scoured stiff & through the thick part of the road where the horses couldn't roll along.
